awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Numerical Methods and Biomechanical Models for Sperm Motility
awd_abstract_narration:
Mammalian sperm must navigate the female reproductive tract, swimming a distance greater than 1000 times their own length to reach and fertilize the egg. In order to aid in the treatment of reduced sperm motility, it is important to understand interactions of the sperm flagellum with different regions of the reproductive tract. In particular, fluid flow helps bring the egg to the uterus (in the opposite direction of sperm progression). Recent experiments have shown that a large percentage of sperm exhibit positive rheotaxis, the ability to reorient and swim against a background flow. Additionally, sperm will bind and unbind to the oviductal wall and the role of a background flow on sperm detachment is not known. The main scientific goals of this project include further analyzing existing experimental data (through image processing techniques) and developing new computational models to understand the clinical importance of migration through the female reproductive tract and sperm binding and detachment from walls in a background flow. Several new computational modeling frameworks will be developed to allow simulations of sperm in the presence of a background flow and a wall. The PI will provide interdisciplinary training for several students (undergraduate and graduate) as well as one postdoc in the areas of computational biofluids, image processing of experimental movies, and model development. In addition, the PI will work to develop image processing and modeling modules to be used in area High Schools and at summer programs for High School students at WPI. 

The sperm flagellum is an elastic structure that propagates waves of bending along its length to propel itself through the female reproductive tract. Understanding the behavior of the interaction between sperm, dynamic elastic structures, and their surrounding fluid will shed light onto the biophysics of their 3-dimensional motion and will help determine the clinical importance of migration through the female reproductive tract in a background flow.  Models will be able to delineate the importance of factors such as sperm rolling, types of flagellar waveforms, biochemistry, and fluid viscosity for forward progression of the sperm.  In this project, the PI will model the sperm flagellum as a Kirchhoff rod that is able to bend and twist.  The rod is able to achieve both planar and nonplanar waveforms and the rotation of the rod can be captured via an orthonormal triad associated with each material point along the centerline of the flagellum. Through this work the PI will focus on the following objectives: (1) Understand the types of emergent waveforms and trajectories of sperm in a background flow at different viscosities; (2) Determine if rolling is due to calcium mediated changes in flagellar waveforms, background flow, wall interactions, or hydrodynamic interactions with other sperm; (3) Investigate the role of background fluid flow on attachment/detachment of sperm to walls; (4) Extend current numerical methods. The PI's research will lead to the development of two new numerical methods to study interactions near a wall and increase accuracy of force calculations through parametric representations of the structure.  These newly developed methods can also be used for other slender elastic structures such as cilia and bacterial flagella.

por.por_cntn:
Mammalian sperm must navigate the female reproductive tract, swimming a distance greater than 1000 times their own length to reach and fertilize the egg. Propulsion is accomplished via the flagellum (tail) propagating bending. The resulting beat form and trajectory is an emergent property of a system coupling local biochemical concentrations, fluid properties, interactions with nearby sperm, and the geometry of the fluid domain. To understand how the sperm reach the egg, and more generally how elastic structures can move and navigate in a fluid, we developed new computational and modeling frameworks. The new methods can be used for any elastic structure in a fluid at the micro-scale and has applications in areas such as the design of micro-robots, micro-fluidic devices, and reproductive biomechanics. 

 

From Idealized 2-Dimensional Models to Fully 3-Dimensional. Sperm flagella are known to exhibit helical and quasi-planar emergent beat forms, which vary based on the surrounding micro-environment. To understand why these beat forms emerge, we must have modeling frameworks that can capture the evolution and transition between different beat forms. We did this by developing a Kirchhoff rod formulation to describe the elastic flagellum, which involved identifying new ways to describe flagellar bending in terms of preferred curvature and twist. Additionally, we developed a new algorithm to determine the resulting fluid flow as a superposition of fundamental solutions where we were now accounting for both forces and torques. This modeling framework was used to study helical and quasi-helical emergent waveforms in different cases such as sperm motility near and away from the oviductal wall as well as in the case of different biochemical concentrations. We have also studied fluid flow around the sperm flagellum to understand how chemicals in the fluid may get trapped close to the flagellum or be pushed further away, important for interactions near the oviductal wall. 

 

Extending Computational Models. Although the use of fundamental solutions is computationally efficient for a small number of structures, it is a method that is O(N2) where N is a product of the number of sperm and the number of discretized points on each swimmer. Thus, simulating thousands of sperm interacting in our framework was intractable until recently when we developed a regularized Stokeslets implementation of the kernel independent fast multipole method,. The interactions are now divided into the near and far field, leading to an equivalent system of equations to solve, which is O(N). Recently, we have extended this method to study the case when the movement of the sperm (or structure) is known, but the forces that generated the movement are unknown. This results in an inverse problem involving a large, dense matrix. In order to solve this in a computationally efficient way, we developed several pre-conditioners. In addition, having a fast and accurate way to calculate forces is an important aspect of modeling fluid-structure interaction problems where forces are based on derivatives related to the structure. Most methods use standard finite-difference approximations, which are often highly oscillatory and require a large number of points in the discretization. We have implemented a radial basis function (RBF)-based parametric representation of the immersed structures in order to reduce the number of discretized points and to achieve higher order accuracy in our force models. We have also explored simulations where sperm are represented as a point with Agent-Based Modeling frameworks. These models have been analyzed and can be used for many applications where there are Agent-Agent or Agent-Environment interactions.

Through this grant, 3 Postdocs, 3 PhD students, and 10 undergraduates at WPI have received interdisciplinary training in modeling, computational methods, and reproductive biomechanics. This work was presented at conferences venues in Mathematics, Computing, and Life Sciences by the PI, as well as the students and Postdocs working on this research. High school students received training in agent-based modeling and image processing of experimental data where parameters are utilized to inform data. Modeling frameworks were also introduced to high school teachers at the Mathematics Institute for Secondary Training at WPI.
